Literature Review: The Paleozoic era marked a pivotal moment in the evolution of insects, with the origin of wings and modifications of postembryonic development being key innovations that would shape the course of insect evolution. While the Mesozoic, Paleogene, and Neogene insect faunas exhibit similarities with the modern one, the Paleozoic fauna provides unique insights into the early stages of insect evolution. This review aims to summarize the recent discoveries related to the documented diversity of Paleozoic hexapods, as well as current knowledge about postembryonic development and the morphology of different body parts. The fossil record suggests that the majority of contemporary insect orders originated in the Late Paleozoic, with estimates of deep divergence ranging from 400 to 500 million years ago. However, these estimates reflect divergences between stem groups of each lineage rather than the later appearance of the crown groups. The initial radiations of the extant hyperdiverse clades during the Early Permian provide evidence of the rapid evolution of insect diversity during this period. The specialized fauna present before the End Permian mass extinction also highlights the adaptability of insects to different environments. One of the most significant innovations in insect evolution is the origin of wings. The earliest known winged insects date back to the Early Permian, with fossils of winged insects found in the Rhynie chert in Scotland. The development of wings is thought to have been driven by the need for insects to escape predators and compete for resources. The morphology of wings has evolved significantly over time, with different groups of insects developing unique wing shapes and structures. In addition to the origin of wings, the Paleozoic fauna also provides insights into postembryonic development. The holometaboly, a process of complete metamorphosis, is thought to have evolved in the Paleozoic era. This process involves a dramatic transformation from a juvenile to an adult form, with distinct stages of development including egg, larva, pupa, and adult. The holometaboly is thought to have evolved as an adaptation to changing environments, allowing insects to exploit new resources and habitats. The fossil record also provides evidence of the diversity of body parts in Paleozoic insects. The development of compound eyes, antennae, and legs has been well-documented in the fossil record. The morphology of these body parts has evolved significantly over time, with different groups of insects developing unique structures and functions. The study of functional morphology has provided insights into the evolution of insect body parts, highlighting the importance of adaptation to environment and function. In conclusion, the Paleozoic fauna provides unique insights into the evolution of insects, including the origin of wings and modifications of postembryonic development. The fossil record highlights the rapid evolution of insect diversity during the Early Permian, as well as the adaptability of insects to different environments. The study of functional morphology has provided insights into the evolution of insect body parts, highlighting the importance of adaptation to environment and function.
